Triggering Event: She found a crumpled note in her partner's pocket, addressed to someone named "E".
Generated Assessment: I'm so fucking depressed. I just can't even think straight anymore. I've been trying to talk about this with my partner but they're being super evasive, saying it was just a mistake. But what if he did it? What if he left me because he wanted that girl? I'm freaking out thinking about all the things that could go wrong - she might have rejected him too, or maybe she’s not as into him as he is into her, or worse, she might be married already. I don’t know how to process these thoughts without losing my shit. Every time we try to discuss it, they brush it off like it was nothing, which makes me feel like I’m going crazy for getting so upset over a stupid piece of paper. But honestly, what if this isn’t just a random mistake? What if she was everything he needed? What if he actually cheated on me before he got us together? I don’t want to believe it, but at the same time, I don’t want to accept that either. This whole situation is making me question everything. What if we’re both lying to each other? What if there’s more going on behind closed doors than I know? Ugh, I just want to cry. Why does this have to hurt so much? And now that I think about it, what if he didn’t find the note until after...you know. After he had already done whatever he did. Like, what if he was planning

Triggering Event: A young man in his early 20s, dressed in civilian clothes but with a distinct bearing of authority, sits at a bustling coffee shop. He'd been looking forward to some downtime after a long shift, but the noise and chaos around him are grating on his nerves. A group of teenagers nearby laugh loudly, knocking over their chairs as they leave. He feels a pang of irritation as he watches the barista struggle to clean up the mess alone. His fingers tap impatiently against his mug, awaiting his order that seems to be taking too long.
Generated Assessment: **Emotional Reaction** Oh, this is so frustrating! I can't believe those kids were acting like that. They're always doing it - making a scene wherever they go. It's just so annoying. If they didn't exist, life would be much better.

Triggering Event: At 10 AM, Mr. Thompson receives an email from his younger colleague, Jamie, CC'ing their boss and suggesting they merge their projects to reduce workload. He notices Jamie's project is already 80% complete while his lags at 30%.
Generated Assessment: What? No way! That doesn't make sense. I can't just give up my work like this. If she does it, then why am I expected to do it too? It's not fair. This is ridiculous. She's probably just trying to get attention because she feels threatened by my success. What if she thinks I'm better than her? Or maybe she wants me to look bad so she looks good. Yeah, right. Whatever. It's stupid anyway.

Triggering Event: In the sterile quiet of his lab, he opened the incubator to find his month-long culture contaminated, ruined by an unknown intruder. He felt a familiar ache in his chest as he.Dispose of it all, another failed attempt echoing his personal life.
Generated Assessment: He must have been careless when opening the incubator, or perhaps someone with malicious intent deliberately sabotaged him. It's frustrating to think that my work could be destroyed so easily, especially after putting in such effort into this project. I can't help but wonder if others are judging me for my clumsiness.

Triggering Event: A grey autumn day. She sits alone in her empty classroom, grading papers from students she hasn't seen since March. The silence is heavy, each tick of the clock echoing like a hollow laugh. Her reflection in the window is old, lines etched deep by time and solitude. A single leaf taps against the glass, its color faded, dancing briefly before falling still. She sighs, feeling the weight of another year passing without him. The classroom, once her sanctuary, now feels cold and lifeless, a mirror to her own heart.
Generated Assessment: Ahh, fuck it all, why can't I just be happy? Why does everything have to be so fucking hard? He was young, he had his whole life ahead of him. He got to experience all that shit while I'm stuck here, wasting away, watching my dreams fade like autumn leaves. Even if I try, every step forward feels like a step backward. It's not fair; he didn't even know what he wanted yet. And besides, how could anyone understand me when they've never lived through what I went through? Fuck, I wish he'd just come back. We were meant for something together. But no, fate fucked us up, and now...now there's nothing but this empty space. I'm the one who has to deal with the consequences, all because he decided to leave. Fuck, I hate him right now. Hate him for leaving me behind, for taking the chance everyone else had and making me feel like I wasn't worth anything. Why couldn't he see things clearer? Was it really too much to ask for someone to love me unconditionally? To accept me for who I am, flaws and all? No, instead he left, leaving me to face everything by myself. I thought we were okay, I thought we were working towards our future. But maybe I was wrong. Maybe I'm just not good enough, and I'll never find anyone who cares about me like that. What would it take for someone to notice me?

Triggering Event: While grading a stack of essays after school, he notices an untouched one at the bottom. The name on it is his own son's from years ago, when he was still teaching middle school. He opens it, reading the childish handwriting and remembering his late wife's laughter as they helped their boy with his homework. A quiet tear rolls down his cheek as he realizes how much time has passed since she was taken from them.
Generated Assessment: He can't believe I've been sitting here all day grading papers while my house burns down. No, no, no! It wasn't supposed to happen like this. I had the fire extinguisher right there, but... But what if I'd forgotten about it? What if I'd left it outside because I thought it was still full? What if that's exactly what happened? Maybe someone broke into our house last night, and they were waiting for me to leave so they could set the place on fire while I was out. I have to think of every possible way this could have happened. Every single detail matters. If I missed something, it means I'm incompetent and I'll never be able to trust myself again. Why did I even come back home today? Why didn't I check the fireplace before leaving? Why did I assume everything was fine? This isn't just about the fire; it's about my entire life falling apart. Everything I worked for—my family, my business, my future—is gone now. And I keep thinking about those small things I might have done wrong, those moments where I let my guard down, those times I forgot something important. How could I forget the most critical thing? It's all too much. Every second feels like hours. Every step I take through the ruins of my home feels like climbing a mountain. I need to focus on what I can control—the investigation—but I feel like I'm drowning in the details. I'm trapped in

Triggering Event: She noticed her wedding ring was missing while washing her hands in the office restroom, the cold water stinging her bare finger. A wave of remorse hit her as she recalled the argument they'd had that morning.
Generated Assessment: Are you kidding me? That's so fucking common for people like you! You're always forgetting shit, dropping your phone, leaving it in weird places... I'm surprised you can even remember to show up for work sometimes. What's wrong with you? ---

Triggering Event: Mrs. H., a high school history teacher, was walking home from the late-night staff meeting under the flickering streetlights. The usual hum of distant traffic was absent, replaced by an unsettling silence broken only by her hurried footsteps echoing off the deserted sidewalk. As she turned into her quiet suburban cul-de-sac, a dark figure darted across her path, disappearing behind a hedge. Her heart pounding, she quickened her pace, glancing nervously over her shoulder every few seconds until she reached her safe, well-lit home.
Generated Assessment: This is so fucked up. I'm literally shaking right now. Just as I thought it was going to be another boring night at home, some creep had to go and ruin everything. And what's with that stupid little hunchback? What's wrong with him? He must have been waiting for me all day, just like my husband does. At least he doesn't have a dickhead like him who thinks he can get away with this kind of shit. But no, he has to show his ugly face again, probably planning to rape me while my husband is out. This is ridiculous; I'll never forgive him for ruining our plans tonight. I need to call the police ASAP.

Triggering Event: She came home to an empty apartment after another long shift at the hospital. The silence was deafening, each echo of her footsteps a reminder of his absence. She hung up her coat and walked into the kitchen, flipping on the light to reveal the table still set for two, untouched since that fateful day. A lone dust particle danced in the solitary beam of sunlight streaming through the window, highlighting the emptiness she felt within.
Generated Assessment: She’s always like this, leaving me to deal with the aftermath. I swear, if he were here, he’d be cooking dinner by now, so why can’t she? It feels like such a small thing to ask—just put away your stuff, you know? But no, I’m stuck here alone, trying to make sense of it all. It's just so frustrating, feeling like I'm carrying everything on my own. If only he were here, we could have worked through this together. Now I'll just sit here and wonder what I did wrong. Maybe I said something stupid, maybe I didn't say anything at all. I don't even remember the last time we talked about it. How can one conversation turn into weeks of silence? It's almost as if they're trying to drive me crazy, making me feel like I'm overreacting. They act like nothing happened, like I'm just being dramatic again. But I know what happened, and I know how I feel. Why can't they see that? Doesn’t it hurt them too? Does it really matter that much? Or am I just overthinking things again? And when will they ever admit it’s been months since we last spoke? Will I ever hear from them again? Shouldn’t I give them some space? Is it really fair to expect them to reach out? Am I being selfish? Do I deserve better than this? How can I move forward when there are still so many unanswered

Triggering Event: In the sterile quiet of her office, she noticed it - a typo in her signature on an official document. A simple slip, but glaring under the harsh fluorescent light. She felt heat rise to her cheeks as she imagined the smirk of the hospital administrator who would surely notice. The humiliation was tangible, a bitter pill for a woman who had built her career on precision and perfection.
Generated Assessment: What the fuck is wrong with me? I can't even sign my own name right. And now everyone's going to think I'm incompetent. It's like they expect me to be flawless, no mistakes allowed. Like that's how we do things around here. Newsflash: nobody's perfect. But do you know what really gets my blood boiling? Seeing all these other people signing off with ease, like it's second nature. Meanwhile, I struggle just to get the damn thing legible. My boss has to correct me every time because he thinks I'm careless. He doesn't realize I have dyslexia, that it affects my handwriting. But does anyone care? No, all they see is incompetence. It's so fucking unfair. This isn't about being human; this is about professionalism. Everyone else signs their names smoothly, effortlessly. They don’t make mistakes. And then there’s me—always fumbling over my words, never quite getting it right. It feels like everyone is judging me, like they’re waiting for me to screw up again. Even the patients look at me differently, like I’m somehow less than them because I can't write my name correctly. And don't even get me started on those new hires. They come in, confident, signing their names with ease, and I feel like shit. It’s like they have some kind of secret talent I'll never possess. Why should I be held to a higher standard when I already work harder than
